name: Hades
subtitle: Lord of the Underworld, God of the Dead
description:
Hades stands as one of the most iconic and influential figures in Greek mythology. Revered as the deity of Underworld, death, the dead, Hades embodies the fundamental forces that shape both the divine and mortal realms. Known as "Lord of the Underworld, God of the Dead", this epithet captures the essence of their divine nature. 

According to Greek sacred texts, Hades's origins trace back to the primordial age, emerging from the cosmic struggle between Titans and Olympians The worship of Hades became central to Greek religious practice, with devotees seeking their favor through temple sacrifices, libations, and participation in sacred festivals. 

Sacred symbols associated with Hades include Helm of darkness, bident, Cerberus. These emblems appear throughout Greek art and literature, serving as powerful reminders of Hades's divine presence and authority. The mythology surrounding Hades reveals deep insights into Greek worldview, particularly concerning Underworld and humanity's relationship with the divine. 

The legacy of Hades extends far beyond ancient Greek civilization. References to Hades pervade Western literature, from Renaissance poetry to modern novels. The archetype continues to influence psychology, philosophy, and popular culture Scholars continue to study Hades's mythology for its profound insights into Greek culture, religion, and philosophy.

topic_panels.content:

### Creation Accounts

Primary sources describe Hades's emergence and divine nature through various sacred narratives. These origin stories served both religious and cultural functions, establishing divine authority and cosmic principles.

**Time Period:** c. 800 BCE - 400 CE

topic_panels.title: Worship & Practice
topic_panels.content:
### Religious Practice

Worship of Hades involved temple sacrifices, festivals, oracles. These practices created sacred bonds between devotees and the divine realm.

### Sacred Sites

Throughout Ancient Greece, Mediterranean basin, temples and shrines dedicated to Hades served as focal points for religious activity. Priests and priestesses maintained sacred rituals that ensured divine favor and cosmic balance.

### Festivals & Ceremonies

Special festivals celebrated Hades's divine attributes and mythological deeds, bringing communities together in shared religious expression.
